utterances: Sabina Rangel was young.
She moved on with her life, got married, had a daughter.
She later divorced and in June of 2000, she tried the military again; this time, in the Navy Reserves.
She was assigned to an Army joint command in El Paso.
She wasn't getting paid on time.
She thought her supervisor was going to going to help.
The command sergeant major at the time, he called me to his office.
And he let me know that if I would meet up with him in a hotel, he would give me money.
And I was like, no, I just need my paycheck.
But the propositions didn't stop.
I finally asked his secretary that when he called me, if he ever closed the door, to please knock on the door.
And she said, Sabina, it happens to everybody.
Dozens of women interviewed for this story spoke about a culture where men act entitled to sex with female troops.
One joked that rape is part of the job description.
Rangel says she tried to avoid ever being alone with the command sergeant major, but he outranked her.
Then I had a mission that I had to go on.
This command sergeant major was there.
He and another sergeant major straight out told me, we were going to have sex.
Rangel reported the rape to her superiors, including a female officer, and they told her to keep quiet.
But other officers started hinting they knew about the rape.
Another sergeant major asked her for sex.
I was really at a breaking point.
I was becoming very depressed.
I contemplated suicide.
Women in the military face a higher risk of being raped multiple times.
Rangel had planned to make the military a career.
She'd earned medals and citations for her work.
Instead, she left in 2006, angry and feeling like she'd never be able to trust anyone.
Rangel says serial sexual predators move up through the service, while women like her are driven out.
They target the ones that are professional, that care about their job, care about their performance.
You know, and then the ones that come from broken families, ran away from whatever atmosphere to join the military and boot camp - those are the people that are targeted.
My name is Jamie.
I was in the Navy for almost six years.
I served on the USS Abraham Lincoln while we deployed to the waters outside of Iraq, the Gulf.
Jamie Livingston grew up all over.
Her stepdad was running from something, she thinks, because they moved from state to state suddenly and without explanation.
She was home-schooled, so no teachers or friends to reach out to.
Like many people, she saw enlisting as an escape to a better life.
I wanted to join the military from the time I was as old as I knew there was a military.
Let me grab this blanket.
I always get cold when I start...
She grabs a comforter, though it's plenty warm.
I wanted to get out of my house, 'cause there was physical, emotional and sexual abuse from as young as I can remember.
Livingston says her stepdad raped her through her teenage years.
As soon as her mom got away from him, Livingston joined the Navy.
She thrived, working on the flight line of an aircraft carrier.
A cruise log - sort of a yearbook - shows pictures of her deployment.
This piece is used to bring back the wire...
The log brings back some good memories - she loved the work - but her chief, her direct supervisor, had a combination lock on the inside of his door.
There was no reason to have a cipher lock on the inside of the door.
You know, obviously, you would have to have the combination to open it.
So any time I would go in there for my qualifications, he would lock that.
And every time that I would get a qualification signed off, he would ask for a sexual favor.
Livingston was later able to join in a successful prosecution against that chief - a rarity among the women we spoke with.
But her troubles didn't end.
Livingston was raped by a group of sailors in a dark storage berth.
She decided to join the military police, in part to help other victims.
I went to become a military police, and I was raped then too, so - (crying) - but I didn't report that one.
I knew the command's attitude towards rape, so I didn't say anything 'cause this guy was my superior, and I had to work with him every day.
The command's attitude toward rape is why most victims don't report.
They're afraid that speaking out can only bring more trouble, and almost never put the rapist behind bars.
Quil Lawrence, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Quil continues his reporting tomorrow.
We'll hear what rape victims can expect from the military justice system.
The military and the VA are looking at alternative ways to treat posttraumatic stress - everything from drugs, to acupuncture, to music and yoga.
But what we'll hear about next is not a standard treatment.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""FIGHT CLUB"")
(As Tyler Durden) I want you to hit me as hard as you can.
(As Narrator) What?
(As Tyler Durden) I want you to hit me as hard as you can.
OK, that was Brad Pitt in the movie ""Fight Club,"" but for a group of veterans in San Diego, getting hit is part of getting better.
NPR'S Quil Lawrence reports.
David Walovich is a catering manager at a local hotel.
He says he's always assumed that President Obama would come out for same-sex marriage.
Walovich says he just didn't think it would come before the election.
I'm sure it's the pressure of the politics of the reelection.
And he said he would move toward that direction eventually.
It just took him a little longer than most people thought.
I think it's a big risk for him to make such an announcement.
One of the risks is that the president is addressing the polarizing social issue at a time when voters want to know what he's doing about the economy.
A few blocks away, William Lynn, an attorney, says he's thrilled that the president spoke up for marriage equality, but wonders about his timing.
I think he was forced by Vice President Biden's comments.
But it's better late than never, right?
But even if Biden's comments over the weekend forced the issue, Lynn says Mr. Obama's new position could be a net-plus for the president's reelection bid.
For one, he'll be assured a lot more financial support from gays and lesbians.
And Lynn says people who oppose gay marriage probably wouldn't vote for the president, anyway.

It's not going to help with the conservative vote, but he might get some of the libertarian people, actually, the uber-libertarian and super-liberal people who might have been dissatisfied with President Obama's first-term performance.
Meanwhile, gay rights activists here were over the moon.
Rebekah Orr is a spokeswoman for Equality California.
She says when she heard the president's comments, she was personally overcome.

And to have the, you know, person who is the highest authority in the land say no matter who you are, no matter who you love, you ought to be able to marry the person that you love and enjoy all of the happiness and security that marriage brings, it's just a really big moment in this movement and in our country.
And Orr says even if some Americans oppose the president's support for gay marriage, at least they will know where he stands.
Richard Gonzales, NPR News, San Francisco.
It's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Jacki Lyden.
The U.S.
and Russia have agreed on a plan to get rid of Syria's chemical weapons by the middle of next year.
Secretary of State John Kerry calls it an ambitious timetable but says he's confident the international community can keep the pressure on Syria to comply.
President Obama welcomed the agreement but says the U.S.
remains prepared to act should the diplomatic route fail.
Coming up, we'll hear how Syria acquired its chemical weapons in the first place.
But first, this agreement caps a week of intensive diplomacy for John Kerry.
NPR's Michele Kelemen is traveling with the secretary and reports from Geneva.
It began with something of an off-the-cuff challenge by Secretary Kerry, who had been making the case for a military strike on Syria.
Kerry told reporters Monday that Damascus could avoid this only if Bashar al-Assad turned over all of his chemical weapons.
But he isn't about to do it, and it can't be done, obviously.
After days of negotiations with Russia on this idea, though, Kerry now says it is doable.
And the language of diplomacy sometimes requires that you put things to the test, and we did.
Russian foreign minister Sergey Lavrov took up that test and stayed longer than expected in Geneva to finalize the deal, which he says was done in record time.
(Foreign language spoken)
These documents are based on consensus, compromise and professionalism, he says.
If Syria doesn't comply, Lavrov says, the U.N.
Security Council will discuss ways to respond.
But there's nothing automatic about that, Lavrov adds, and Russia won't preapprove any action.
He says he wasn't even in touch with Syria during the course of these negotiations.
